sequence.notes: Formation of a dithioacetal from an aldehyde using ethanethiol and hydrochloric acid.
Formation of a bis-acetonide from a polyol (1,2,3,4-tetrahydroxy-5,5-bis(ethylsulfanyl)pentane derivative) and acetone under acid catalysis.
Base-promoted elimination of an ethylthio group from a dithioacetal to form a vinyl sulfide, accompanied by the hydrolysis of one isopropylidene acetal to a secondary alcohol.
Reduction of the carbon-carbon double bond in the ketene dithioacetal derivative.
Hydrolysis of an acetonide protecting group to reveal a 1,2-diol.
Selective protection of the primary alcohol as a TBDPS ether.
Intramolecular cyclization forming a furanose ring from an open-chain polyol, involving the hydrolysis of a dithioacetal to an aldehyde, followed by hemiacetal formation at the anomeric carbon.
Di-acetylation of two secondary alcohol groups on a furanose ring.
Sakurai allylation of anomeric acetate with allyltrimethylsilane, converting the anomeric acetate to an allyl group with inversion of configuration (from ~OAc to alpha-allyl).
Alkene hydroboration-oxidation to a primary alcohol.
Protection of a primary alcohol with monomethoxytrityl (MMTr) group.
Hydrolysis of acetate ester to hydroxyl group.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone in a furanose derivative.
Deprotection of monomethoxytrityl (MMTr) ether to a primary alcohol. TBDPS ether remains intact.
Tebbe olefination of a ketone to an exocyclic methylene group.
Esterification of primary alcohol with pivaloyl chloride to form pivalate ester.
Deprotection of TBDPS silyl ether to primary alcohol.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde using Dess-Martin periodinane.

Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons olefination of an aldehyde to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone with a stereocenter and an iodo-methylidene group, preserving a furanose ring with two stereocenters and a pivaloate protecting group.

substeps.notes: Reduction of a carboxylic acid to a primary alcohol using borane. The lactone ring remains intact.
Silyl ether formation (protection of a primary alcohol with TBDPSCl)
Alpha-alkylation of a gamma-lactone to introduce a methyl group at the alpha-position to the carbonyl, maintaining the stereochemistry of the existing chiral center and forming a new one.
Nucleophilic attack of methyllithium on a chiral lactone, opening the ring to form a secondary alcohol and a methyl ketone.
A secondary alcohol is protected as a tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether using TBSCl and imidazole. The TBDPS group and the stereochemistry of the methyl group are retained.
Methyl ketone converted to a hydrazone with TrisNHNH2, retaining stereochemistry.
Shapiro reaction converting a silyl hydrazone to a vinyl stannane. The 'TrisHNN' in the reactant is interpreted as a tert-butyldiphenylsilyl hydrazone based on the input SMILES's attempt.
Replacement of a vinyl tributylstannane with iodine to form a vinyl iodide. Stereochemistry of chiral centers is retained.
Deprotection of TBDPS and TBS silyl ethers to primary and secondary alcohols.
Oxidation of a vicinal diol to an aldehyde using sodium periodate. One chiral center is retained, the other is lost due to the formation of the aldehyde.
Oxidation of an aldehyde to a carboxylic acid using Jones reagent. Stereochemistry at the chiral center is retained.
(3 steps)
Addition of a lithiomethyl phosphonate to a benzyl ester, converting the ester to a ketone with an adjacent phosphonate group. The stereocenter is retained.

sequence.notes: Alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone reduced to saturated ketone via Stryker reduction.
Stereoselective reduction of a ketone to a secondary alcohol using sodium borohydride.
Secondary alcohol is converted to a mesylate (MsO) group.
Vinyl iodide undergoes Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi coupling with aldehyde to form a C-C bond and a new secondary alcohol.

substeps.notes: Two hydroxyl groups of the dihydropyran are protected as tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ethers.
Alkylation of a secondary alcohol with benzyl bromide to form a benzyl ether.
Deprotection of two TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) protecting groups to yield hydroxyls.
Di-esterification of primary and secondary hydroxyl groups with propionic anhydride.

Ester converted to silyl enol ether via deprotonation with lithium bis(trimethylsilyl)amide (LiHMDS) and silylation with tert-butylchlorodimethylsilane (TBSCl). Stereochemistry of chiral centers and the enol ether double bond were corrected. Note: The reagent text shows 'TBSCl' but the product structure shows 'OTMS'. The generated SMILES for the reagent reflects TBSCl, and the product SMILES reflects OTMS, matching the respective representations in the screenshot, indicating a possible inconsistency in the original image.
Intramolecular Ireland-Claisen rearrangement of an O-silylated ketene acetal to form a carboxylic acid, creating two new chiral centers.
Hydrolysis of an ethyl ester to a primary alcohol under basic conditions.
Intramolecular iodolactonization of an unsaturated carboxylic acid to form a bicyclic lactone with simultaneous introduction of an iodide.
Radical reduction of an alkyl iodide using tributyltin hydride.
DIBAL reduction of lactone to hemiacetal, followed by methylation to a mixed acetal.

Formation of a bicyclic spiroketal system from a hexose derivative via intramolecular acetal formation, indicated by the loss of one hydroxyl group and formation of a new ring. The anomeric carbon in the product is shown with a wavy bond, indicating a mixture of anomers.
Primary alcohol is converted to a triflate (trifluoromethanesulfonate) ester, activating it for subsequent reactions. All stereocenters remain unchanged.
Conversion of a primary alcohol's triflate ester to a nitrile via nucleophilic substitution using sodium cyanide.
Reduction of a nitrile to an aldehyde using DIBAL-H, followed by acidic workup.
Reduction of an aldehyde to a primary alcohol using sodium borohydride.
Catalytic hydrogenation using Pearlman's catalyst (Pd(OH)2/C) cleaves the benzyl ether protecting group to yield a free hydroxyl group.

The bicyclic sugar derivative undergoes anomeric substitution and furanose ring opening, where the methyl anomeric group is replaced by a dithioacetal group, creating an acyclic chain from the furanose portion, while the pyranose ring remains intact. BF3 OEt2 acts as a Lewis acid catalyst for the conversion of the anomeric O-glycoside to the dithioacetal.
Protection of three hydroxyl groups with TBSCl to form silyl ethers.
Dithioacetal is oxidized/hydrolyzed to form an aldehyde. All TBS protecting groups remain unchanged.
Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi reaction: An aldehyde reacts with a vinyl iodide in the presence of nickel(II) chloride and chromium(II) chloride to form an allyl alcohol.
Trichloroacetimidate mediated p-methoxybenzyl ether formation on a secondary alcohol.
Deprotection of three TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) ether groups to hydroxyl groups using HF-pyridine.
Formation of a 1,3-dioxane acetal from a 1,3-diol using 2,2-dimethoxypropane and PPTS.

substeps.reaction_type: Intramolecular Reductive Cyclization / Intramolecular Michael Addition
substeps.notes: Intramolecular cyclization involving a secondary alcohol and an α,β-unsaturated methyl ester. The double bond is reduced, and a new 6-membered cyclic ether is formed.
Hydrolysis of a cyclic acetonide to generate a 1,3-diol.
Two hydroxyl groups are protected as tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ethers.
Reduction of a methyl ester to a primary alcohol using lithium aluminum hydride, without affecting TBS or OMPM protecting groups.
Dess-Martin oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.

sequence.notes: An intramolecular cyclization via nucleophilic attack of a deprotonated hydroxyl group on a carbon bearing a mesylate leaving group, forming a new 6-membered ether ring.
Pivalate ester is reduced to a primary alcohol. Other protecting groups (TBSO, OMPM) remain unchanged.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.
Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi reaction between an aldehyde and a vinyl iodide to form a new carbon-carbon bond and a secondary alcohol.

substeps.notes: Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.
Ketone at C3 of a di-O-isopropylidene furanose derivative is reduced to a secondary alcohol with a specific stereochemistry (OH down, H up) using sodium borohydride.
O-benzylation of the C3 hydroxyl group of 1,2:5,6-di-O-isopropylidene-α-D-glucofuranose.
Hydrolysis of 1,2- and 5,6-O-isopropylidene acetals to diols and formation of a methyl glycoside at the anomeric position.
Diesterification of two hydroxyl groups to mesylates.

Double SN2 substitution of two mesylate (MsO) groups with acetate (AcO) groups. This reaction involves inversion of configuration at the stereocenter bearing the leaving group, specifically at C5 of the furanose side chain.

Hydrolysis of two acetate (AcO) protecting groups to hydroxyl (OH) groups using sodium methoxide in methanol. All other protecting groups (isopropylidene ketal, benzyl ether) and stereocenters are retained.
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of an isopropylidene acetal protecting group to yield a diol.
Ring expansion of furanose to pyranose with glycosidation (methyl acetal formation). Yield is for 2 steps.
All available hydroxyl groups (one primary and two secondary) are benzylated. The existing benzyl ether and anomeric methoxy group remain untouched.

Sakurai allylation of a protected glucopyranoside, where the anomeric methoxy group is replaced by an allyl group. Stereochemistry at C1 is changed from unspecified (wavy bond) to beta-allyl (dotted wedge).
Birch reduction to deprotect four benzyl ethers to alcohols. The allyl group is retained.
Acetylation of all four hydroxyl groups to their acetate esters.

Hydroboration-oxidation of the allyl group to a primary alcohol. The stereochemistry of C3 in the reactant, and C2 and C4 in the product were corrected. Acetate groups were abbreviated to [OAc] to match the screenshot representation.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde using Swern oxidation conditions, with preservation of stereochemistry and acetate protecting groups.
Wittig olefination of an aldehyde to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ester.
All acetate groups are hydrolyzed. The alkene is reduced, and an intramolecular cyclization occurs to form a bicyclic furanose-pyranose system.

Selective benzoylation of the primary hydroxyl group on a complex bicyclic acetal, leaving secondary alcohols untouched. The stereocenter at the alpha carbon to the methyl ester, which is shown with a wavy bond in the reactant and product, has its stereochemistry removed from the SMILES. The benzoyl group is abbreviated as [OBz] to match the screenshot representation.
Formation of a cyclic acetal from a diol and an acetal reagent.
Base-catalyzed epimerization/equilibration of a stereocenter (indicated by a wiggly bond in the reactant) to a defined stereochemistry in the product.
Acid-catalyzed deprotection of a p-methoxybenzylidene acetal to yield vicinal diols.
Diol protection to form bis-TBS ether
Selective debenzoylation of a primary benzoate ester to a primary alcohol using sodium methoxide.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde using Swern conditions. The bicyclic structure, stereochemistry, and TBS protecting groups are correctly represented.
Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi reaction to convert an aldehyde to a propargylic alcohol using iodo(trimethylsilyl)acetylene.
Desilylation of a TMS-protected terminal alkyne.
Radical hydrostannylation of a terminal alkyne to form an E-vinylstannane.
Conversion of a vinyl tributyltin derivative to a vinyl iodide.
Silylation of a secondary alcohol using TBSOTf and triethylamine.

sequence.notes: Oxidation of a secondary allylic alcohol to an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone.
Deprotection of p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) ether to a hydroxyl group using DDQ.

Methyl ester (-COOMe) in the reactant is hydrolyzed to a carboxylic acid (-COOH) in the product. All five 'TBSO' groups, abbreviated in the screenshot, were expanded as 'triethylsilyl' (TES) in the provided SMILES (`O[Si](CC)(CC)CC`). These have been corrected to the proper 'tert-butyldimethylsilyl' abbreviation `[OTBS]` to match the visual representation. The current product SMILES contains multiple stereochemical differences and potential ring closure inconsistencies when compared to the reactant SMILES (e.g., at C2 and neighboring carbons, and the repetition of 'O2)'). These changes should not occur during a simple ester hydrolysis.
Macrolactone formation via Yamaguchi lactonization between a carboxylic acid and a secondary alcohol.
Deprotection of five TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) ethers to hydroxyl groups.
Acid-catalyzed intramolecular cascade cyclization involving a lactone, an alkene, and an alcohol, forming a complex polycyclic ether cage and a cyclic acetal.
Esterification of a primary alcohol with 4-nitrobenzoyl chloride.
Protection of secondary alcohol as TBS ether.
Deprotection of p-nitrobenzoate ester to alcohol using potassium carbonate in methanol.
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde using Dess-Martin periodinane.
Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi reaction of an aldehyde with an organochromium reagent to form a secondary alcohol.

substeps.notes: Addition of a methyl group to an alpha,beta-unsaturated lactone, resulting in reduction of the double bond and introduction of a new chiral center.
Reduction of a gamma-lactone to a 1,4-diol using lithium aluminum hydride.
Protection of a primary alcohol with a TBDPS group in the presence of an acetal and a secondary alcohol.
The hydroxyl group is protected as a p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) ether using 4-methoxybenzyl bromide (MPMBr) and potassium fluoride (KF).
Acetonide protecting group is hydrolyzed to a 1,2-diol using aqueous acetic acid. Stereochemistry of the other chiral centers is preserved.

Intramolecular cyclization of a 1,2-diol (after activation of one alcohol) to form an epoxide. Primary alcohol is deprotonated, then attacks the secondary alcohol carbon to form the epoxide. Stereochemistry of the methyl and OMPM groups is preserved. The cis-epoxide is formed, with the oxygen bridging 'up'.
Cleavage of a TBDPS silyl ether to yield a primary alcohol.
(2 steps)

Nucleophilic ring opening of an epoxide by an acetylide, forming a new C-C bond and a secondary alcohol. The stereochemistry of the newly formed alcohol (R) implies an inversion from the original epoxide carbon (S) and retention of the less substituted epoxide carbon as a methylene, which is unusual for a typical SN2-like epoxide opening mechanism but matches the drawn product.
Selective partial hydrogenation of an internal alkyne to a cis-alkene using Lindlar catalyst. All stereocenters remain unchanged.
Epoxidation of a cis-alkene to form a cis-epoxide with the oxygen atom oriented 'up'. The stereochemistry of other chiral centers and protecting groups are retained.

substeps.reaction_type: Acid-catalyzed epoxide opening and cyclization, MPM deprotection
substeps.notes: Intramolecular cyclization of an epoxide with an adjacent hydroxyl group forms a tetrahydrofuran (THF) ring. Concurrently, the 4-methoxybenzyl (MPM) protecting group is cleaved under acidic conditions to yield a free hydroxyl group.
Hydrolysis of an isopropylidene acetal to a triol using aqueous acetic acid. The reaction proceeds in 3 steps.
Four hydroxyl groups are protected as tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ethers. The pivalate ester remains unchanged.
Pivalate ester reduction to a primary alcohol.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde using Dess-Martin periodinane.
Organolithium reagent adds to an aldehyde, forming a secondary alcohol.
TMS deprotection of terminal alkyne.
Radical hydrostannylation of a terminal alkyne using n-Bu3SnH and AIBN to form an E-vinylstannane. Stereochemistry of all chiral centers is preserved.
Conversion of a vinylstannane to a vinyl iodide.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.

sequence.notes: Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone using Dess-Martin periodinane.

The primary transformation shown is the deprotection of three TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) ethers to hydroxyl groups. The alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone remains unchanged in the product. The text 'Michael reaction' below the arrow appears to be a descriptor of a broader reaction sequence or conceptual idea, but does not reflect the specific transformation depicted in this step.

Deprotection of p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) ether to a hydroxyl group. The original input SMILES for reactant and product were highly divergent and did not accurately represent this single step transformation; thus, they could not be directly corrected. Instead, correct SMILES for Halichondrin B (product) and its 25-O-p-methoxybenzyl derivative (reactant) were generated.

Intramolecular cyclization of polyol precursor to form the polycyclic ether system of Halichondrin B under acidic conditions. This overall transformation is reported to proceed in 3 steps, likely involving multiple intramolecular reactions such as aldol condensations, Michael additions, and ether formations.
